sentences.sentence: However, I worked hard, till my strength was almost gone, and kept my boat as close to the shore as possibly I could.
At about noon, I felt a little bit of wind in my face.
In about half an hour more, it blew pretty strongly.
By this time I had gone a long distance from the island, but the wind continued.
I let the wind carry me back directly towards the island, although about two miles north from where I had started.
When I had reached a distance of perhaps a mile from the shore, the wind suddenly stopped, and helped me no more.
However, I found that the water was calm, and with a great deal of effort at rowing, in about an hour I got to land.
When I was on shore, I fell on my knees( 跪下 ) and gave God thanks for saving me, deciding to drop my plans of saving myself with my boat.
I had now had enough of( 受够了… ) going to sea for some time, and had enough to do for many days just to sit and think about the danger I had been in.
Soon after this voyage I finished my fourth year in this place.
On the anniversary( 周年纪念日 ) of my arrival in this place, I observed that there was a strange relationship of days in the various events which happened to me.
The same day that I broke away from my father in order to go to sea, was the same day of the year afterwards I was made a slave.

That same day of the year that I escaped out of that ship in Yarmouth Roads was the same day of the year afterwards I made my escape from Sallee in a boat. The same day of the year I was born on— the 30th of September was the same day I had my life so miraculously saved,
when I was cast on shore in this island; so that my wicked life and my lonely life began both on the same day.
With these thoughts I made my mind up, not only to surrender( 屈服 ) to the will of God in my circumstances( 情况 ), but even to give sincere( 真诚的 ) thanks for my condition.
In the first place( 首先 ), I was removed from all the evil( 罪恶，邪恶 ) of the world here.
I lacked nothing, for I had all that I was now capable( 能够…的 ) of enjoying.
If I pleased, I might call myself king or emperor over the whole.
I had enough to eat and supply my wants, and what was all the rest to me?
I had now brought my state of life to be much easier than it was at first, and much easier to my mind, as well as to my body.
It was here on this island that I realized that all unhappiness comes from a lack of thankfulness for what we have.
For six years, nothing extraordinary happened to me.
I lived on in the same way, and in the same place, as before.
You are to understand that now I had, as I may call it, two homes on the island.
One was my tent, with the cave behind me. Near this shelter( 住所 ) of mine lay my “farm”, which I kept farmed and planted.
Besides this, I had my little cottage. It was here, whenever I was away from my main shelter( 住所 ), that I took up my country home.
One day, when I was near the shore by my country home, I was extremely surprised to see the print of a man’s foot on the sand.
I stood completely still, as if I had seen a ghost( 鬼 ).
I listened, I looked round me, but I could neither hear nor see anything.
I went up the shore and down the shore, but I could see no other prints except that one.
I looked to see if there were any more, and to see if it might not be my imagination.
But it was exactly the print of a foot—toes( 脚趾 ), heel, and every part of a foot.
When I came to measure the mark with my own foot, I found my foot was not anywhere near as large.
I came home to my shelter( 住所 ), terrified( 恐慌的 ), looking behind me every two or three steps.
When I came to my castle, for so I think I called it ever after this, I ran into it like a man being chased( 追逐 ).
I did not sleep that night, but asked myself throughout( 自始至终 ) the night, “How is it possible a man could come here?”
I presently concluded( 得出结论 ) then that it must be some of the natives from the mainland.
They must have wandered out to sea in their boats, and been on shore, but then gone away again to sea.
I was very thankful that I was not near there at that time.
Then terrible thoughts attacked my imagination.
What would happen if they found me? Or perhaps they would find my shelter( 住所 ), and destroy all my corn, and then I would die from hunger.
Thus my fear destroyed all my religious hope, and all my previous confidence in God.
I blamed myself for my laziness, and for not planting any more corn than I needed to last till the next harvest.
I decided to always keep two or three years’ worth of( 可维持两三年时间的 ) corn saved for the future, so that, whatever might come, I might not die for lack of food.
So I lived there safely, in my usual way, for another six years.
I began now to notice that my gunpowder( 火药 ) had decreased( 减少 ) considerably.
This was something which it was impossible for me to supply.
I began to wonder how I could kill any goats without gunpowder( 火药 ).
I had previously kept a baby goat, and raised her up tame( 驯服的 ), but she had died at last of old age.
I thought about how to trap goats.
I particularly wanted a pregnant( 怀孕的 ) goat who would give birth to( 生育 ) baby goats.
I dug several large holes in the earth, in places where I had observed the goats feeding( 进食 ), and over those holes I placed sticks and leaves and so on.
A few days after, I found inside one of these holes two male goats, and three baby goats, and two females.
Taking them one by one, I tied them with strings( 细绳 ), and with some difficulty brought them all home.
It was a good while before they would feed( 进食 ), but after I started feeding( 喂养 ) them some of my sweet corn, they began to be tame( 驯服的 ).
It occurred to( 突然想到 ) me that I must keep the goats secure by surrounding( 包围 ) them with some sort of fence, or else they would always run wild( 变得狂野 ) when they grew up.
My first work was to find a proper piece of ground.
This needed to have grass for them to eat, water for them to drink, and cover to keep them from the sun.
For this purpose, I decided to fence a little bit of land, as hidden as I could make it, where I could keep about half a dozen young goats.
I spent some time exploring the most remote parts of the island, and finally chose one which was as private as my heart could wish.
It was a little damp( 潮湿的 ) piece of ground in the middle of the thick woods, where I found a natural cave in the earth.
I observed also that there was a place where the cave continued further.
Here it was so low that it required me to crawl( 爬 ) upon my hands and knees to go into it.
The next day I came back with six large candles of my own making, for I made very good candles now of goat’s fat.
Going into this low place of the cave, I was forced to crawl( 爬 ) on my hands and knees, but beyond this narrow piece, I found the roof rise up nearly twenty feet.
Never was such a glorious sight seen in the island.
The wall reflected a hundred thousand lights to me from my two candles.
I knew not what it was in the rock, whether diamonds or any other precious( 珍贵的 ) stones, or gold which I rather supposed it to be.
I decided to bring my gunpowder( 火药 ) to here, and all my spare weapons( 武器 ).
I immediately went to work on this piece of ground surrounding( 包围 ) this cave.
In less than a month’s time I had fenced it well enough round that my goats were secured in it.
This suited my needs, and in about a year and a half I had about twelve goats.
In two years more I had forty three, besides several that I took and killed for my food.
But this was not all, for now I not only had goat’s meat to feed on( 以...为食 ), but milk too, and I made both butter and cheese at last.
What a table was here spread for me, in the wilderness( 荒地 ) where I thought at first I would die from hunger!
